quote.quotepara: Yes, it works. I don't think it's any better or worse than signing the location value, but the operations required (dereference at every step) is a pain. It's functional. Consider that the TLS operation needs the very same cert that you would use to sign, the crypto operations are roughly similar, and the security is pretty much the same.
No. You missed one crucial and important operation: data canonicalization. Signing the data requires it, using TLS does not. And replay attacks can be thwarted. Plus, it isn't patent encumbered.

body.para: And all machinery is in-place, from a geopriv perspective.
